Dean Shaffer's speech to the
freshmen seemed to imply that
Hopkins administration would
institute a significant policy
change in its dealings with the
undergraduate student body.
Although in the past the University has been quite liberal in
its controls over student life, it
has recently expressed some discontent at such diverse student
activities as drinking in the
stands during athletic events,
fraternity misdemeanors, and
protest rallies held during addresses given by visiting lecturers.
The administration apparently
feels that student government
is not sufficiently strong to preserve the academic and social
Image of the University. Recent
action prohibiting alcoholic beverages in the stadium may serve
to forewarn the student of
further University restrictions
that would channel his energies
toward more constructive goals.
University officials will endeavor to prevent the occurrence
of any Berkeley-type situation
by making it clear that the student is essentially "free" only in
his capacity to either attend the
Institution and abide by its rules
or not come at, all.

Institute, the expedition will be
searching for traces of the
Zapotec civilization, which flourished long before the Aztecs.

"There are evidences that the
Zapotecs began turning from
hunting and wildplant gathering
to agricultural economy 7000
years ago."

What's so nice about this place
If I were in a local laundry and found the attendants
advocating the wearing of dirty clothes or even disclaiming the establishment of laundries in general, the entire
performance being approved by the executive, I would
think it queer.
By the same token, I first thought queer the introduction the Students for a Democratic Society made
to the students:
"All in all," the message said "being a student
at Johns Hopkins is a pretty big deal ... there
are worse alternatives ... you could be out
working for a living for instance ... or you
could be adding to the growing statistics of
'Youth Unemployment.' . . . provided of
course, that you managed not to he drafted
to spill your guts out in defense of the Way
of Life of some Asian or Latin American government. While we, in SDS share in appreciation for our lives as University students, and
while we don't necessarily disparage career
aspirations, we feel that prevalent views of the
relationship between th student and his activities in the University contain assumptions
which, unless challenged, would limit the extent to which our lives could he rich and meaningful."
Clearly, the tnessage confronts die Freshmen with
the thesis that going to college is second place to fighting the real world and its ills. It suggests that the University itself is liable to criticism, and that as long as
we're here, our lives could be richer by attacking the
local wrongs.
There are others, on the contrary, who dote on
the necessity of morality and legality within the campus
community; a community not really noted for its cohesion nor even for being a community.
"We," say the Student Council,"act as the ruling body over all campus organizations so as
to keep the entire extra-curricular program
running smoothly. We, of course are the main
line of communication between the students
and faculty as shown by the Student Faculty
Forum run under the Council auspices each
fall."
And "we," say the Honor Commission, give
you an Honor System which is "a way of life."
It applies to every action of the individual.
It is something not imposed from without but
realized within. Living under the Honor System cannot leave an individual unchanged.
"Students must live up to the Honor System
as well as live under it. To fail is to fail oneself
and the community, as well as to break with a
long and noble tradition."
We are all in truth, whether dissenter or co-joiner,
whether we play lacrosse or play with our professors,
we are all clients of a cash-and-carry educational supplies dispensary. The Johns Hopkins faculty to student
relationship is truly a business relationship, an objective,
somewhat detached market place for items of destiny.
And for this reason, this relationship ranges from attendant to pedant to agitant to militant and so on.

such that they are considered capable of purchasing a
decent destiny.
No doubt some of the "client students" are poor
shoppers, some ought send their mothers to shop for
them, and some are in the store merely to get out of
the rain. And it is bewildering and almost imperfect that
a University contains this diversity; not only contains it
but incorporates it. We like it that way.

If I were in a local laundry and found the attendants
advocating the wearing of dirty clothes or even disclaiming the establishment of laundries in general, the entire
performance being approved by the executive, I would
think it queer.
By the same token, I first thought queer the introduction the Students for a Democratic Society made
to the students:
"All in all," the message said "being a student
at Johns Hopkins is a pretty big deal ... there
are worse alternatives ... you could be out
working for a living for instance ... or you
could be adding to the growing statistics of
'Youth Unemployment.' . . . provided of
course, that you managed not to he drafted
to spill your guts out in defense of the Way
of Life of some Asian or Latin American government. While we, in SDS share in appreciation for our lives as University students, and
while we don't necessarily disparage career
aspirations, we feel that prevalent views of the
relationship between th student and his activities in the University contain assumptions
which, unless challenged, would limit the extent to which our lives could he rich and meaningful."
Clearly, the tnessage confronts die Freshmen with
the thesis that going to college is second place to fighting the real world and its ills. It suggests that the University itself is liable to criticism, and that as long as
we're here, our lives could be richer by attacking the
local wrongs.
There are others, on the contrary, who dote on
the necessity of morality and legality within the campus
community; a community not really noted for its cohesion nor even for being a community.
"We," say the Student Council,"act as the ruling body over all campus organizations so as
to keep the entire extra-curricular program
running smoothly. We, of course are the main
line of communication between the students
and faculty as shown by the Student Faculty
Forum run under the Council auspices each
fall."
And "we," say the Honor Commission, give
you an Honor System which is "a way of life."
It applies to every action of the individual.
It is something not imposed from without but
realized within. Living under the Honor System cannot leave an individual unchanged.
"Students must live up to the Honor System
as well as live under it. To fail is to fail oneself
and the community, as well as to break with a
long and noble tradition."
We are all in truth, whether dissenter or co-joiner,
whether we play lacrosse or play with our professors,
we are all clients of a cash-and-carry educational supplies dispensary. The Johns Hopkins faculty to student

somewhat detached market place for items of destiny.
